post-flight reconstruction so for post light reconstruction
what you see on the left is an infrared view of one of our first flights now the

was a tilt back and forth of the vehicle now we varied we have very detailed
simulations of the vehicle as it as it both boosts as well as lands and these
were outside of what we were expecting in that data review now what we ended up
doing is generating a fault tree that fault tree looked at a lot of different
potential causes of the back-and-forth tilt the first would simply be that the
engine on aerodynamics that plume on arrow was affecting the static stability
of the vehicle we also looked at the fact that that shedding plume as it goes
up the sides of the vehicle were causing some kind of disturbances that was basically pushing the vehicle back and
forth there was potential for control coupling effects between the engine
control as well as the aft fins and there's also just the ineffectiveness of
as those basically hot fluid cells roll up past the a fins that the Africans
were less effective than they had been predicted to be what you see in the bottom right here are the test data from
those early flights the Blues the raw data the green is a 10 Hertz Gaussian

were able to quickly kind of rule out the the vehicle static stability that was done through kind of hand
calculations as well as simulation studies the control coupling effects were also
ruled out through through simulation we looked at stability margins associated
with the aerodynamics and determined that that was not a factor however the potentially the aft fin
effectiveness had a potential probability to be a root cause and then
the unsteady shedding of the plume and the disturbances had high probability
but we wanted to vet that out so what we did is we turn to unsteady CFD and so
we're steady CFD is trying to look at a
constant flow field unsteady CFD assumes you basically let the flow field evolve
with time and you're looking at the unsteady dynamics that this would cause what we did is we did it attached to any
simulation of the the vehicle at different angles of attack different fuss levels and it was about a five
million cell CFD simulation covering about a two to three second time window that matched the data points that we had
and in the post flight data review and what we showed is that those cells that
were flowing up past the vehicle could in fact impart the magnitude of disturbances that we were looking at and
so between the unsteady simulation as well as some sixth off Monte Carlo we
were able to basically prove out the theory and validate that that was the
leg of the fault tree that was actually causing these disturbances then once we knew an idea of what was causing it
we couldn't redesign the hardware to prevent this we have to fly through that plume so what we ended up doing was
modifying the flight software and so the flight software modifications ended up
kind of in three different areas what we did first was when we land we actually
have a reference profile that we expect the engine to perform with based off of kind of an optimal use of fuel to get us
back to the landing pad that what we did is modify that kind of high thrust cap that allow the engine to
basically restart more aggressively and faster there's also an interesting play
between the thrust vector control and aft fins and so what we did was faded in
the TV can TV see control earlier and detuned some of the aft fin control so
we were able to modify the balance between which effectors we use to be
able to kind of stabilize the vehicle at the end part of flight and then we also basically has restarted lower as the
